issue.title: Remove attribute `type` from `<sensor>` and infer type from child tags

content.raw: The type is used to distinguish between different implementation types. Take the `gpuray` and `ray` sensor types as an example. Both of these sensors use the `<ray>` child element.
content.html: The type is used to distinguish between different implementation types. Take the gpuray and ray sensor types as an example. Both of these sensors use the <ray> child element.

issue.title: Remove attribute `type` from `<sensor>` and infer type from child tags

content.raw:
Hmm. Is there a way to capture `gpu_ray` vs `ray` and allow custom sensors?

Looking at the gazebo implementations `gpu_ray` sees the geometry on `<visual>` elements while `ray` sees the geometry on`<collision>`. If that distiction became part of sdformat by splitting `<ray>` into `<visual_ray>` and `<collision_ray>` then this proposal would work for that case.

issue.title: Remove attribute `type` from `<sensor>` and infer type from child tags

content.raw:
Right, we can still remove the `type` attribute, but we'd have to expand the set of child elements. 

Type is useful in cases where child data would be duplicated. I think there are a few sensors that use the `<camera>` child elements with different `type` attributes. 

We could also make `type="custom"` as a valid sensor `type`.
content.html:

We could also make type="custom" as a valid sensor type.

issue.title: Remove attribute `type` from `<sensor>` and infer type from child tags

content.raw: While de-duplicating the type info would be nice, I have to admit adding `type="custom"` is a small change that solves the issue.

The multi camera has multiple child `<camera>` elements:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/8a59b5f0f0b9bda21ee905098b47900da492ba9c/test/worlds/multicamera_test.world?fileviewer=file-view-default#multicamera_test.world-63:90

~~~
        <sensor name="cam2" type="multicamera">
          <update_rate>20</update_rate>
          <camera name="left">
            <horizontal_fov>1.3962634</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>1024</width>
              <height>544</height>
              <format>L8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>100</far>
            </clip>
          </camera>
          <camera name="right">
            <pose>0 -0.1 0 0 0 0</pose>
            <horizontal_fov>1.3962634</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>1024</width>
              <height>544</height>
              <format>L8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>100</far>
            </clip>
          </camera>
        </sensor>
~~~
